fr:title.text: The role of interchange in diagrammatic reasoning

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The role of interchange in diagrammatic reasoning

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In a 2-category, interchange is strict; in particular, this means that vertical composition and horizontal composition commute strictly with each other. This is very useful for String diagrams, but it is not strictly necessary. In a string diagram, strict interchange means that 2-cells can be freely moved upward and downward; so if you want to use diagrammatic reasoning to study something in a structure that has only weak interchange, you need two things:

html:ol.html:li: The vertical position of a 2-cell is fixed.
No two 2-cells should appear at the same vertical position.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To move a 2-cell up or down is to insert an interchange cell. It is this principle that makes homotopy.io work.

There is a common thread in modern approaches to domain theory, theory of computation, and topology: one has an object \Sigma with two points \bot ,\top :\Sigma that behave like the Sierpiński space, and it induces a binary “order” relation on any other object by serving as an interval: in particular, for a space X and points x,y:X we may say that x\sqsubseteq y when there exists a mapping H\colon \Sigma \to X such that H\bot = x and H\top = y. This is called the path order.

In addition to the path order described above, the Sierpiński space has its own intrinsic order: for p,q:\Sigma we say that p\leq q when p=\top implies q=\top . The Phoa principle is an important law governing the Sierpiński space ensuring that the path order and the intrinsic order coincide.

The map \Sigma ^\Sigma \to \Sigma \times \Sigma sending f to the pair {\mathopen {}\left (f\bot ,f\top \right )\mathclose {}} is an embedding and its image is the subset of \Sigma \times \Sigma spanned by pairs {\mathopen {}\left (p,q\right )\mathclose {}} such that p=\top implies q=\top .

A concrete model of domain theory (like cpos) is always a poset-enriched category, which can also be thought of as a (locally posetal) 2-category. I have discovered that it is possible to re-formulate Phoa’s principle in terms of 2-categorical universal properties of comma and cocomma squares, and it can be shown that in a cartesian closed locally posetal 2-category, an appropriate version of Phoa’s principle always holds.

In fact, an appropriate version of Phoa’s principle should hold in any cartesian closed 2-category (including non-posetal ones), and the proposal is to prove that this is the case using string diagrams. This result will have implications for the understanding of higher-dimensional domain theory as applied to concurrency.
